Award.AwardTitle: Iowa Lakes Community College Infinity Scholars Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
PROJECT ABSTRACT

Iowa Lakes Community College's Infinity Scholars program is designed to unify a diverse group of talented STEM students with academic preparation for a successful transition to a university or the workforce. Each year, up to 30 scholarship recipients are to engage in career exploration conferences, undergraduate research with a capstone event featuring participant research, professional portfolio development, membership in the Iowa Academy of Science, and a STEM Exploration Trip. Additionally, faculty mentoring and cohort study table activities are planned to increase student retention to degree achievement. At graduation, Iowa Lakes' Infinity Scholars are well-prepared to become leaders and innovators in technical areas of national need.

Intellectual Merit: The program builds upon Iowa Lakes' first S-STEM program in which 144 participants maintained an average GPA of 3.50, well above the college average of 2.76. Experienced Principal Investigators plan to expand this success through the addition of more intensive career exploration, participation in goal-focused cohorts, and professional networking. The Infinity Scholars program success is to be measured against eligible, non-participant student baseline data for Iowa Lakes and STEM degree programs in a project database.

Broader Impacts: The Infinity Scholars program is to advance learning and discovery through participant travel, professional networking, and opportunities for undergraduate research. Iowa Lakes' designation as the Northwest Iowa STEM Hub is to allow program information to be quickly disseminated to gifted students throughout the region and the state, and will be an effective means for recruiting individuals from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Iowa Lakes Community College, a community college in rural northwest Iowa, is proud to have been awarded the NSF S-STEM grant, which was known as the Infinity Scholars program. Over five years, one hundred forty-seven (147) Infinity Scholars received scholarship funds. In addition to scholarships, Infinity Scholars were matched with a faculty mentor to guide them through their academic career, managed a research project of their own design, presented the results of their research to the public and at professional conferences, and were provided the opportunity to travel to urban areas to learn about advanced education and careers in STEM. Results of the program were disseminated at a variety of conferences across the United States for STEM professionals and educators.

 

Infinity Scholars persisted or graduated from Iowa Lakes Community College at a rate of 80.3%. The graduation rate for Iowa Lakes Community College students at large was 38.7%; for the Infinity Scholars cohorts, the graduation rate was 64.6%. The transfer rates for the general student population was 26.4%; for the Infinity Scholars cohorts, the transfer rate was 37.4%.

 

Intellectual Merit

The design of the Infinity Scholars program was highly successful. Infinity Scholars built strong relationships with their faculty mentors based on their collaboration in research and academic advising. Interdisciplinary relationships created by Infinity Scholars and faculty working together across disciplines on research projects will be maintained beyond the end date of the program. Infinity Scholars built enduring relationships within their cohorts, which will provide them with a network of professionals as they start their careers.

 

Broader Impacts

Infinity Scholars demonstrated higher levels of parity in participation based on sex than is often seen in STEM fields; 59.9% were male, and 40.1% were female. Recruiting efforts to draw and maintain females in STEM programs will continue at Iowa Lakes Community College.

Many of the Infinity Scholar graduates are currently working in STEM fields within the state and region, constructing and maintaining wind turbines, working with livestock genetics, and managing public forests, for example. Others have transferred to colleges and universities and are pursuing degrees in disciplines such as mathematics, engineering, and biology.

For many students from a geographically rural area, travelling to large cities such as Denver or Chicago were new experiences for them, especially with the ability to see the STEM careers that would be available as they continue their education and enter the workforce.


Last Modified: 10/19/2017
Modified by: Robert R Klepper
